natural problem: An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$?
natural solution: I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.

So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.

So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.

(For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> dice i \<and> dice i \<le> 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> dice i \<noteq> dice j"
and h2 : "\<exists> m n. dice m = red \<and> dice n = red \<and> m \<noteq> n \<and> dice m + dice n \<noteq> 7"
shows  "card {i. dice i = red} = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes dice :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> dice i \<and> dice i \<le> 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> dice i \<noteq> dice j"
and h2 : "\<exists> m n. dice m = red \<and> dice n = red \<and> m \<noteq> n \<and> dice m + dice n \<noteq> 7"
shows  "card {i. dice i = red} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A die is rolled and each face shows a number from 1 to 6. No two faces show the same number. If there are exactly two faces that show red and the sum of the numbers on these two faces is not 7, prove that exactly two faces show red.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "a \<le> 6"
and h2 : "b \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "b \<le> 6"
and h4 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h5 : "a + b \<noteq> 7"
shows  "card {(a, b). a \<noteq> b \<and> a + b \<noteq> 7} = 12"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "a \<le> 6"
and h2 : "b \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "b \<le> 6"
and h4 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h5 : "a + b \<noteq> 7"
shows  "card {(a, b). a \<noteq> b \<and> a + b \<noteq> 7} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many pairs of distinct integers (a, b), where 1 ≤ a ≤ 6 and 1 ≤ b ≤ 6, have the property that their sum is not equal to 7? The final answer is 12.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> f n = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n m. f n + f m = 7 \<longrightarrow> f n \<noteq> 2 \<and> f m \<noteq> 2"
shows  "card {n. \<exists>m. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 6 \<and> f n = 2 \<and> f m = 2} = 12"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> f n = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n m. f n + f m = 7 \<longrightarrow> f n \<noteq> 2 \<and> f m \<noteq> 2"
shows  "card {n. \<exists>m. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 6 \<and> f n = 2 \<and> f m = 2} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ defined on the natural numbers where for all $n$ such that $1 \leq n \leq 6$, $f(n) = 1$. Also, for all $n$ and $m$, if $f(n) + f(m) = 7$, then $f(n) \neq 2$ and $f(m) \neq 2$. How many pairs of numbers $(n, m)$ are there such that $1 \leq n \leq 6$, $1 \leq m \leq 6$, $f(n) = 2$ and $f(m) = 2$? The final answer is 12.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. \<forall> j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (die i + die j \<noteq> 7)"
shows  "card { (i,j) | i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<and> i \<noteq> j } = 12"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes die :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. \<forall> j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (die i + die j \<noteq> 7)"
shows  "card { (i,j) | i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<and> i \<noteq> j } = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: How many distinct pairs of numbers can you get from two six-sided dice, excluding pairs that add up to 7 and pairs with the same number on both dice? The final answer is 12.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a + b \<noteq> 7 \<longrightarrow> a \<le> 6 \<and> b \<le> 6"
shows  "card {(a, b) \<in> S \<times> S. a \<noteq> b \<and> a + b \<noteq> 7} = 12"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a + b \<noteq> 7 \<longrightarrow> a \<le> 6 \<and> b \<le> 6"
shows  "card {(a, b) \<in> S \<times> S. a \<noteq> b \<and> a + b \<noteq> 7} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a set containing numbers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, how many pairs of different numbers can be formed such that their sum is not equal to 7? The final answer is 12.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_faces :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "card red_faces = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x \<in> red_faces \<and> y \<in> red_faces \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> x + y \<noteq> 7"
shows  "card {red_faces. card red_faces = 2 \<and> (\<forall>x y. x \<in> red_faces \<and> y \<in> red_faces \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> x + y \<noteq> 7)} = 12"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_faces :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "card red_faces = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x \<in> red_faces \<and> y \<in> red_faces \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> x + y \<noteq> 7"
shows  "card {red_faces. card red_faces = 2 \<and> (\<forall>x y. x \<in> red_faces \<and> y \<in> red_faces \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> x + y \<noteq> 7)} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A dice game has a special set of two faces marked in red. The sum of numbers on any two different red faces cannot be 7. How many such distinct sets of red faces can there be? The final answer is 12.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes A :: "nat set"
and B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "B = {x+y |x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x+y \<noteq> 7}"
shows  "card B = 12"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem 
fixes A :: "nat set"
and B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "B = {x+y |x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x+y \<noteq> 7}"
shows  "card B = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: The set A contains the numbers 1 through 6. The set B is made up of all the sums of two distinct numbers from A that do not add up to 7. How many elements are in set B? The answer is 12.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(int \<Rightarrow> int) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>x. x 1 \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6} \<and> x 2 \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6} \<and> x 1 \<noteq> x 2 \<and> x 1 + x 2 \<noteq> 7)"
shows  "card {x. f x} = 12"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "(int \<Rightarrow> int) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>x. x 1 \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6} \<and> x 2 \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6} \<and> x 1 \<noteq> x 2 \<and> x 1 + x 2 \<noteq> 7)"
shows  "card {x. f x} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ which takes as input a function from integers to integers. $f$ is such that it holds true if the input function evaluated at 1 and 2 yields two distinct numbers in the set $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ such that their sum is not 7. How many such input functions make $f$ true? The final answer is 12.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "set (map die [1..6]) = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. (die x = die y) = (x = y)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. (x \<noteq> y) \<longrightarrow> (die x + die y \<noteq> 7)"
shows  "card {(x,y) | x y. x \<noteq> y \<and> die x + die y \<noteq> 7} = 12"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes die :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "set (map die [1..6]) = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. (die x = die y) = (x = y)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. (x \<noteq> y) \<longrightarrow> (die x + die y \<noteq> 7)"
shows  "card {(x,y) | x y. x \<noteq> y \<and> die x + die y \<noteq> 7} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a die with faces numbered from 1 to 6. If the sum of the numbers on any two different faces is not equal to 7, how many such pairs of faces are there? The final answer is 12.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_ways ways_sum_7 :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "total_ways = 6 choose 2"
and h1 : "ways_sum_7 = 3"
shows  "total_ways - ways_sum_7 = 12"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An ordinary $6$-sided die has a number on each face from $1$ to $6$ (each number appears on one face). How many ways can I paint two faces of a die red, so that the numbers on the red faces don't add up to $7$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 I can pick one face in $6$ ways. Then, I have $4$ choices for the second face, because I can't pick the first face again, nor can I pick the unique face with which it makes $7$.
 So I seem to have $6\cdot 4 = 24$ choices -- but this actually overcounts the possible results by a factor of $2$, because in the end, it doesn't matter which of the two red faces I chose first and which I chose second.
 So the actual number of possibilities is $24/2$, or $\boxed{12}$. There's another neat way to see this! If you have an ordinary die, you may notice that the pairs of numbers which add up to $7$ are all on pairs of opposite faces.
 (For example, the $1$ is opposite the $6$.) This means that in order to paint two faces that don't add up to $7$, I must choose any two faces that aren't opposite. Two faces that aren't opposite must share an edge, and there is exactly one pair of faces meeting along each edge of the die.
 Since a cube has $12$ edges, there are $\boxed{12}$ choices I can make.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_ways ways_sum_7 :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "total_ways = 6 choose 2"
and h1 : "ways_sum_7 = 3"
shows  "total_ways - ways_sum_7 = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If the total number of ways to choose 2 items from a set of 6 is reduced by the number of ways to sum 7 from the same set, which is 3, what is the remaining number of ways? The final answer is 12.
